post_text:
FAQ: Athletics Summer Voluntary Workouts
These workouts are NOT required for participation in Central Athletics Programs

Q: Is this just high school practices, or will middle school sports be operating?
A: These are summer strength and conditioning workouts for 9th - 12th grade students involved in any sports team (Fall, Winter, or Spring Sports). This is not open to 6th - 8th grade students.

Q: What if my kid is going into the 9th grade. How do they contact coaches to be a part of the practices, since there has not been registration?
A: Students may pick up this evening 5 to 7 p.m. at Central High School in the parking lot behind the stadium to get the appropriate paperwork to complete to be eligible to participate in summer strength and conditioning workouts. (All incoming freshman are to attend Session two beginning at 10:15.)

Q: Are all fall sports doing this?
A: The summer strength and conditioning workouts are for 9th - 12th grade students involved in any sports team (Fall, Winter, or Spring Sports).

Q: How will the forms be handed out when we pick up waivers? Can we print them off line so we don't have to come to school at all?
A: Forms will be handed out July 2nd from 5-7pm in the parking lot behind the stadium and can be downloaded from the district Facebook page or website and printed.

Q: How can we stop the spread if we allow conditioning to begin? As the numbers rise, why would the district allow this to happen? (Now masks are mandatory in businesses)
A: All activities conducted will adhere to the guidelines set by the CDC, OHA, NFHS, and OSAA for current allowed practices and training.

Q: How can coaches keep them from not sweating all over equipment and then 10 more kids touch it? Is there equipment?
A: Strength and Conditioning activities will take place outdoors, and any and all equipment will be sanitized at each use.

Q: Are students allowed to use those squeeze water bottles and share with friends if their lips don't touch them?
A: All students are required to bring their own water bottle. No sharing of water is allowed. A touchless refill station can be made available if necessary.

Q: What is the guidance from the Superintendent if a student-athlete contracts covid-19 while conditioning?
A: Students should not come to practices if they show any signs of being ill, or if they suspect they have been exposed to someone with COVID-19 or any other sickness. Symptoms include cough, chills, fever, sore throat, muscle pain, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, and new loss of sense of taste or smell. All coaches and students will be screened daily for signs / symptoms of COVID-19 prior to participating. Responses to screening questions for each person will be recorded and stored along with their temperature taken via a touchless thermometer. Any person with positive symptoms reported will not be allowed to participate, should self-isolate, and contact their primary care provider or other health-care professional.

Q: How is the school going to keep our athletes from socializing in the parking lots after the conditioning is done? They will still be on school grounds, so technically it's the schools responsibility to keep them separated?
A: It will be clearly communicated throughout students' time on campus to adhere to any and all regulations. Staff will make it clear and advise student-athletes to not linger in the parking lot after these voluntary practices and workouts. Students will be advised to physically distance from each other if waiting for parents/family members.

post_text:
Parents! This is the link you've been waiting for! Let us know what instructional model you'd prefer for next fall:

Preferred instructional model survey

Dear Central School District 13J Families,

We have been hard at work, getting ready for the 2020-21 school year. We have developed concepts for hybrid learning models -- a mix of in-person and comprehensive distance learning. We are building programs and protocols to meet the guidance from the Oregon Department of Education and the Oregon Health Authority. As we receive more guidance, our plans will adjust. Remember, we don't make the timeline. The virus makes the timeline.

Each plan addresses our priorities and guiding principles:
Health and safety protocols for all stakeholders -- students, staff, families, community.
One day a week dedicated to deep cleaning and disinfecting. Time to allow for thorough cleaning and sanitizing of spaces between groups of students and staff.
Students on-site at least four days a week, with a priority focus on K-5, migrant, emerging bilinguals, students experiencing disabilities, and high-risk students.
Provide social connections for students, face-to-face with physical distancing and online
Instruction will focus on Social-emotional learning, literacy, math; graduation credits for our high school students; comprehensive online and in-person programs; and engaging learning -- project-based learning and experiential learning.
Two meals each day for students, whether they are in class or off site.
Visitors will be highly restricted.

Due to the health protocols mandated by the state, it won't be possible to have all students back in school all at once, as they were pre-coronavirus. We can't guarantee the 35-square-feet per person required to maintain physical distance in classrooms, nor the distance requirements on school buses. Some of the models we have examined would place students in two groups with staggered starts. While one group is in the classroom, the other would be online, for example. These models are not listed in any type of priority order from a district perspective.

Model 1
K-5, with K-3 the priority: 4 days a week in classrooms; 6-8 A/B schedule: 1-2 days per week in classrooms (Two groups, or cohorts, alternating days); 9-12 schedule: 1-2 days per week in classrooms.
Model 2
K-5, with K-3 the priority: 4 days per week. Students are at school 3.5 hours per day (Two cohorts, or groups, morning and afternoon sessions); 6-12 in comprehensive distance learning
Model 3
K-5, with K-3 the priority: 5 days a week. Students are at school 3.5 hours per day (two cohorts, or groups, morning and afternoon sessions). Rotation day on a Wednesday for groups every other week; 6-12 in comprehensive distance learning
Model 4
All students enroll in a fully virtual distance learning program, with onsite intervention and/or facilitated learning in classrooms and distance learning centers. K-5, with K-3 as the priority on site, 4 days a week. 6-12 would also have in-person check-in at schools or other locations (distance learning centers) in the community at least one day a week.

These hybrid learning models will allow us to move in and out of comprehensive distance learning in response to possible future mandated closures. Cohorts, or groups of students, would be encouraged to remain together through class, lunch and recess, with limited mixing of groups to limit potential exposure to Covid-19. To maintain the small groups mandated by ODE's guidance, we may have to use all the spaces available. What this means for you: Your student may not be attending their home school for part or all of the school year in 2020-21.

What we need from you: Please answer a brief survey to let us know which model you prefer. Your input is important to us, and will help us create the best model for our students and community.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdI2kX92DQXVN2-bWs1auwQOJyR5i_Z1tZ2ovI7CbiXNtBGKg/viewform

Encuesta de Modelo Instructivo Preferido
Estimadas familias del Distrito Escolar Central 13J,
Hemos estado trabajando arduamente, prepar√°ndonos para el a√±o escolar 2020-21. Hemos desarrollado conceptos para modelos de aprendizaje h√≠brido, una mezcla de aprendizaje a distancia integral y en persona. Estamos construyendo programas y protocolos para cumplir con la gu√≠a del Departamento de Educaci√≥n de Oreg√≥n y la Autoridad de Salud de Oreg√≥n. A medida que recibamos m√°s orientaci√≥n, nuestros planes se ajustar√°n. Recuerda, nosotros no hacemos la l√≠nea de tiempo. El virus hace la l√≠nea de tiempo.
Cada plan aborda nuestras prioridades y principios rectores:

Protocolos de salud y seguridad para todas las partes interesadas: estudiantes, personal, familias, comunidad.
Un d√≠a a la semana dedicado a la limpieza profunda y desinfecci√≥n. Tiempo para permitir una limpieza y desinfecci√≥n a fondo de espacios entre grupos de estudiantes y personal.
Los estudiantes en el lugar al menos cuatro d√≠as a la semana, con un enfoque prioritario en K-5, migrantes, biling√ºes emergentes, estudiantes que experimentan discapacidades y estudiantes de alto riesgo.
Proporcionar conexiones sociales para los estudiantes, cara a cara con distanciamiento f√≠sico y en l√≠nea.
La instrucci√≥n se centrar√° en el aprendizaje socioemocional, la alfabetizaci√≥n, las matem√°ticas; cr√©ditos de graduaci√≥n para nuestros estudiantes de secundaria; programas integrales en l√≠nea y en persona; y aprendizaje divertido - aprendizaje basado en proyectos y aprendizaje experiencial.
Dos comidas al d√≠a para los estudiantes, ya sea en clase o fuera del sitio.
Los visitantes estar√°n muy restringidos.
Debido a los protocolos de salud exigidos por el estado, no ser√° posible tener a todos los estudiantes de vuelta a la escuela de una sola vez, ya que eran pre-coronavirus. No podemos garantizar los 35 pies cuadrados por persona requeridos para mantener la distancia f√≠sica en las aulas, ni los requisitos de distancia en los autobuses escolares. Algunos de los modelos que hemos examinado colocar√≠an a los estudiantes en dos grupos con inicios escalonados. Mientras que un grupo est√° en el aula, el otro estar√≠a en l√≠nea, por ejemplo.
Estos modelos no se enumeran en ning√∫n tipo de orden de prioridad desde una perspectiva de distrito.
Modelo 1
K-5, con K-3 la prioridad: 4 d√≠as a la semana en las aulas; 6-8 horario A/B: 1-2 d√≠as por semana en las aulas (dos grupos, d√≠as alternos); 9-12 horario: 1-2 d√≠as por semana en las aulas.
Modelo 2
K-5, con K-3 la prioridad: 4 d√≠as por semana. Los estudiantes est√°n en la escuela 3,5 horas al d√≠a (dos grupos, sesiones de ma√±ana y tarde); 6-12 en aprendizaje integral a distancia
Modelo 3
K-5, con K-3 la prioridad: 5 d√≠as a la semana. Los estudiantes est√°n en la escuela 3,5 horas al d√≠a (dos grupos, sesiones de ma√±ana y tarde). D√≠a de rotaci√≥n un mi√©rcoles para grupos cada dos semanas; 6-12 en aprendizaje integral a distancia
Modelo 4
Todos los estudiantes se inscriben en un programa de aprendizaje a distancia totalmente virtual, con intervenci√≥n en el sitio y/o aprendizaje facilitado en aulas y centros de aprendizaje a distancia. K-5, con K-3 como prioridad en el lugar, 4 d√≠as a la semana. 6-12 tambi√©n tendr√≠a check-in en persona en escuelas u otros lugares (centros de aprendizaje a distancia) en la comunidad al menos un d√≠a a la semana.

Estos modelos de aprendizaje h√≠brido nos permitir√°n entrar y salir del aprendizaje a distancia integral en respuesta a posibles cierres futuros. Se alentar√≠a a los grupos de estudiantes, a permanecer juntos durante la clase, el almuerzo y el recreo, con una mezcla limitada de grupos para limitar la exposici√≥n potencial a Covid-19. Para mantener los peque√±os grupos ordenados por la gu√≠a de la ODE, es posible que tengamos que utilizar todos los espacios disponibles. Lo que esto significa para usted: Es posible que su estudiante no asista a su escuela designada conforme a su direcci√≥n durante parte o la totalidad del a√±o escolar en 2020-21.
Lo que necesitamos de usted: Por favor, responda una breve encuesta para hacernos saber qu√© modelo prefiere. Su opini√≥n es importante para nosotros, y nos ayudar√° a crear el mejor modelo para nuestros estudiantes y la comunidad.
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdI2kX92DQXVN2-bWs1auwQOJyR5i_Z1tZ2ovI7CbiXNtBGKg/viewform

post_text:
Hello Student-Athletes! Please see the announcement below:
UPDATE: Information about times:
Session 1: 8-9:30 a.m. Check-in time at 7:40 a.m.
Session 2: 10:15 a.m. to 12:10 p.m. Check-in time at 10 a.m. Freshmen will attend the second session.
More details about the practice agenda will be available at practice.

Sesi√≥n #1: De 8 a 9:30 a.m. Horario de registro 7:40 a.m.
Sesi√≥n #2: De 10:15 a.m. a 12:10 p.m. Horario de registro 10 a.m. Los alumnos de noveno grado asistir√°n a la segunda sesi√≥n.
M√°s detalles sobre la agenda de pr√°ctica estar√°n disponibles en la pr√°ctica.

Dear Central School District families and student-athletes,
As we get ready for summer-workout season, we want to provide student-athletes with opportunities to return to modified activities in full accordance with guidelines from both the Oregon Health Authority and OSAA beginning July 6.

Before any student can participate in these voluntary workouts, they and their parent or guardian must sign a waiver provided by the district. Waivers may be picked up at the parking lot behind the stadium Thursday, July 2, from 5 to 7 p.m. All coaches and students will be screened each day prior to participation. As they check in at the sanitizing station, they will need to answer screening questions provided by OHA. Answers will be recorded, and their temperatures taken via a "no touch" thermometer.

Workouts for general athletics will be done Monday through Thursday in the morning, outdoors on the turf, and will consist of general strength and conditioning sessions.

Each session will consist of athletes working in pods of 10 or fewer. These pods will remain the same for the entire session and week. Each pod will have its own station. All facilities will have a regular cleaning schedule, and locker rooms will not be made available. Any equipment used by a pod will be wiped down and disinfected at the end of each session. The total number of athletes and coaches will be limited to 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors within any facility.

Students must bring their own water bottle. A contact-free water refill station can be provided. No water fountains or troughs will be used. Multiple sanitizing stations will be placed throughout the facility, including the entrance and the exit, to encourage regular sanitizing.

One coach will oversee all activities and ensure guidelines are followed.

Students will check in via the lower parking lot on the northeast corner for the start of the session -- maintaining physical distance of six feet apart -- and leave the facility via the northwest parking lot of the school.

We continue to build the 2020-21 school year, and do not yet have guidance on what the athletics program will look like in fall. These carefully monitored and crafted, volunteer workout sessions are one way we can bring student-athletes and coaches back together and back to work on conditioning and training. We appreciate your patience and understanding through this process.

Estimadas familias del Distrito Escolar Central y estudiantes-atletas,
A medida que nos preparamos para la temporada de entrenamiento de verano, queremos proporcionar a los estudiantes-atletas oportunidades de volver a las actividades modificadas de acuerdo con las directrices de la Autoridad de Salud de Oreg√≥n y OSAA a partir del 6 de julio.
Antes de que cualquier estudiante pueda participar en estos entrenamientos voluntarios, ellos y sus padres o tutores deben firmar una exenci√≥n proporcionada por el distrito. Las exenciones se pueden recoger en el estacionamiento detr√°s del estadio el jueves 2 de julio, de 5 a 7 p.m. Todos los entrenadores y estudiantes ser√°n evaluados cada d√≠a antes de la participaci√≥n. Al registrarse en la estaci√≥n desinfectante, tendr√°n que responder a las preguntas de selecci√≥n proporcionadas por OHA. Se registrar√°n las respuestas, y sus temperaturas se tomar√°n a trav√©s de un term√≥metro "sin contacto"
Los entrenamientos para el atletismo general se realizar√°n de lunes a jueves por la ma√±ana, al aire libre en el c√©sped, y consistir√°n en sesiones generales de fuerza y acondicionamiento.
Cada sesi√≥n consistir√° en atletas que trabajan en grupos de 10 o menos. Estos grupos seguir√°n siendo las mismas durante toda la semana y la sesi√≥n. Cada grupo tendr√° su propia estaci√≥n. Todas las instalaciones tendr√°n un horario de limpieza regular, y los vestuarios no estar√°n disponibles. Cualquier equipo utilizado por un grupo ser√° limpiado y desinfectado al final de cada sesi√≥n. El n√∫mero total de atletas y entrenadores estar√° limitado a 50 personas en interiores y 100 personas al aire libre dentro de cualquier instalaci√≥n.
Los estudiantes deben traer su propia botella de agua. Tambi√©n hay una estaci√≥n de recarga de agua sin contacto. No se utilizar√°n fuentes de agua ni valles. Se colocar√°n m√∫ltiples estaciones desinfectantes en toda la instalaci√≥n, incluyendo la entrada y la salida, para fomentar la desinfecci√≥n regular.
Un entrenador supervisar√° todas las actividades y se asegurar√° de que se sigan las pautas
Los estudiantes se registrar√°n en el estacionamiento inferior en la esquina noreste para el comienzo de la sesi√≥n - manteniendo distanciamiento f√≠sico de seis pies de distancia - y dejar√°n la instalaci√≥n a trav√©s del estacionamiento del noroeste de la escuela.
Seguimos construyendo el a√±o escolar 2020-21, y todav√≠a no tenemos orientaci√≥n sobre c√≥mo ser√° el programa de atletismo en oto√±o. Estas sesiones de entrenamiento voluntarias cuidadosamente monitoreadas y elaboradas son una manera en que podemos reunir a los estudiantes-atletas y entrenadores de nuevo y volver a trabajar en el acondicionamiento y el entrenamiento. Agradecemos su paciencia y comprensi√≥n a trav√©s de este proceso.

Al registrarse en la estaci√≥n desinfectante, tendr√°n que responder a las preguntas de selecci√≥n proporcionadas por OHA. Se registrar√°n las respuestas, y sus temperaturas se tomar√°n a trav√©s de un term√≥metro "sin contacto"
Los entrenamientos para el atletismo general se realizar√°n de lunes a jueves por la ma√±ana, al aire libre en el c√©sped, y consistir√°n en sesiones generales de fuerza y acondicionamiento.
Cada sesi√≥n consistir√° en atletas que trabajan en grupos de 10 o menos. Estos grupos seguir√°n siendo las mismas durante toda la semana y la sesi√≥n. Cada grupo tendr√° su propia estaci√≥n. Todas las instalaciones tendr√°n un horario de limpieza regular, y los vestuarios no estar√°n disponibles. Cualquier equipo utilizado por un grupo ser√° limpiado y desinfectado al final de cada sesi√≥n. El n√∫mero total de atletas y entrenadores estar√° limitado a 50 personas en interiores y 100 personas al aire libre dentro de cualquier instalaci√≥n.
Los estudiantes deben traer su propia botella de agua. Tambi√©n hay una estaci√≥n de recarga de agua sin contacto. No se utilizar√°n fuentes de agua ni valles. Se colocar√°n m√∫ltiples estaciones desinfectantes en toda la instalaci√≥n, incluyendo la entrada y la salida, para fomentar la desinfecci√≥n regular.
Un entrenador supervisar√° todas las actividades y se asegurar√° de que se sigan las pautas
Los estudiantes se registrar√°n en el estacionamiento inferior en la esquina noreste para el comienzo de la sesi√≥n - manteniendo distanciamiento f√≠sico de seis pies de distancia - y dejar√°n la instalaci√≥n a trav√©s del estacionamiento del noroeste de la escuela.
Seguimos construyendo el a√±o escolar 2020-21, y todav√≠a no tenemos orientaci√≥n sobre c√≥mo ser√° el programa de atletismo en oto√±o. Estas sesiones de entrenamiento voluntarias cuidadosamente monitoreadas y elaboradas son una manera en que podemos reunir a los estudiantes-atletas y entrenadores de nuevo y volver a trabajar en el acondicionamiento y el entrenamiento. Agradecemos su paciencia y comprensi√≥n a trav√©s de este proceso.

post_text:
Dear CSD 13J families and community,

This week, we've taken the first steps in preparing for what school will look like in fall 2020-21. Our administrative team has reviewed the lengthy requirements provided by the Oregon Department of Education to both educate students and keep them safe. We know that health and safety will be our priority moving into 2020-21, as well as caring for each student's social and emotional health, and furthering their academic progress.

We've walked through all of our facilities and created an inventory of available class spaces, including at our new Ash Creek Annex. We've started to identify an advisory committee comprised of members who represent the multiple facets of our community, from public health representatives to community partners, parents, staff members and youths. We will be reaching out to them in coming weeks.

We are in the very beginning stages of drafting detailed plans for the start of school, including safety protocols for students, staff and families, as well as how we will care for the social, emotional and physical health of our students, staff and communities while teaching our students essential standards. Families, please watch for a survey in July as we continue to gather information to support the 2020-21 school year planning.

Our Ready Schools, Safe Learners plan will be reviewed and approved by the board of directors by Aug. 10, and submitted to the Oregon Department of Education for approval by Aug. 14. We will send updates to our families and communities throughout the process, as well as posting to our website, central.k12.or.us, and our district Facebook page.

If you have any specific questions or concerns, feel free to reach out to info@central.k12.or.us, and we will get back to you as soon as we can.

Estimadas familias y comunidad del Distrito Escolar Central 13J,

Esta semana, hemos dado los primeros pasos en la preparaci√≥n para ver c√≥mo se ver√° la escuela en el oto√±o 2020-21. Nuestro equipo administrativo ha revisado los largos requisitos proporcionados por el Departamento de Educaci√≥n de Oreg√≥n para educar a los estudiantes y mantenerlos seguros. Sabemos que la salud y la seguridad ser√°n nuestra prioridad al iniciar el ciclo escolar 2020-21, as√≠ como cuidar la salud social y emocional de cada estudiante, y promover su progreso acad√©mico.

Hemos caminado a trav√©s de todas nuestras instalaciones y creado un inventario de espacios de clase disponibles, incluyendo en nuestro edificio nuevo anexo a Ash Creek. Hemos comenzado a identificar un comit√© asesor compuesto por miembros que representan las m√∫ltiples facetas de nuestra comunidad, desde representantes de salud p√∫blica hasta socios comunitarios, padres, miembros del personal y j√≥venes. Nos comunicaremos con ellos en las pr√≥ximas semanas.

Estamos en las etapas iniciales de la redacci√≥n de planes detallados para el inicio de la escuela, incluyendo protocolos de seguridad para estudiantes, personal y familias, al igual de c√≥mo cuidaremos de la salud social, emocional y f√≠sica de nuestros estudiantes, personal y comunidades mientras ense√±amos a nuestros estudiantes est√°ndares esenciales. Familias, por favor, est√©n al pendiente de una encuesta que se har√° en julio mientras continuamos recopilando informaci√≥n para apoyar la planificaci√≥n del a√±o escolar 2020-21.

Nuestro plan ‚ÄúReady Schools‚Äù Escuelas Listas, ‚ÄúSafe Learners‚Äù Aprendices Seguros ser√° revisado y aprobado por la junta directiva antes del 10 de agosto, y enviado al Departamento de Educaci√≥n de Oregon para su aprobaci√≥n antes del 14 de agosto. Enviaremos actualizaciones a nuestras familias y comunidades durante todo el proceso, as√≠ como publicar en nuestro sitio web, central.k12.or.us y nuestra p√°gina de Facebook del distrito.

Si tiene alguna pregunta o inquietud espec√≠fica, no dude en ponerse en contacto por correo electr√≥nico a info-central.k12.or.us y nos pondremos en contacto con usted tan pronto como podamos.

City of Independence
June 18 at 1:36 PM ¬∑

If you have been to Riverview Park lately, you probably noticed these posts.

Here's a message from our public library for a rundown of the Story Walk at the park!

"Check out our Story Walk at Riverview Park. What's a Story Walk? A Story Walk is an innovative and fun way for children - and adults - to enjoy a story as you take a walk. We've had really good feedback about it, so we will probably do a second one in July and/or August."

Here is the link to a short slideshow on the library's Facebook page:
https://www.facebook.com/watch/?v=280122039837254

Declaraci√≥n de la Mesa Directiva del Distrito Escolar Central 13J, la Superintendente Jennifer Kubista, la Asociaci√≥n Central de Educaci√≥n y la Asociaci√≥n de Empleados Escolares de Oreg√≥n Cap√≠tulo 124 sobre el asesinato de George Floyd y la necesidad de abordar el racismo institucional en nuestras escuelas p√∫blicas:

Estimadas familias, personal y comunidad del Distrito Escolar Central 13J,

En las √∫ltimas semanas, hemos alzado nuestra voz y nuestro coraz√≥n hacia aquellos que han
sido marginados y maltratados a causa de su raza, por ser afroamericanos o hispanos. El racismo sist√©mico en nuestra naci√≥n ha sido llevado a la vanguardia de la conciencia de nuestra comunidad por la reciente muerte de George Floyd y Breonna Taylor, y muchos otros. Creemos que la educaci√≥n es un derecho fundamental. Hemos hecho un esfuerzo concertado para organizar nuestro distrito en torno a los valores identificados por nuestros estudiantes, nuestro personal, nuestras familias y
nuestra comunidad. Nuestras partes interesadas claramente quieren escuelas que sean inclusivas, diversas, equitativas, seguras, respetuosas y enfocadas en todo el ni√±o.

Sin embargo, reconocemos que, como una organizaci√≥n predominantemente blanca, es
fundamental que nos apoyemos en conversaciones inc√≥modas y realmente nos desafiemos
a escucharnos y nos empujemos a encarnar un aliado verdadero y significativo. Debemos tratar de tomar medidas directas encaminadas a elevar a nuestros estudiantes que pertenecen a comunidades que han sido marginadas y atacadas durante demasiado tiempo. En el contexto de nuestras escuelas p√∫blicas, eso significa establecer pol√≠ticas y reglamentos equitativos; proporcionar un aprendizaje profesional centrado en la equidad de raza y pr√°cticas de ense√±anza culturalmente receptivas; reexaminar nuestros sistemas de disciplina; la
creaci√≥n de caminos para que los educadores de color entren y permanezcan en la
educaci√≥n para que nuestras escuelas reflejen mejor la diversidad de nuestras
comunidades; y capacitar a nuestros educadores para incorporar significativamente la raza y la equidad racial en el plan de estudios.

Es el deber fundamental de los educadores elevar a los oprimidos, y para el Distrito
Escolar Central, que incluye abordar cualquier forma de discriminaci√≥n o racismo que exista en nuestras escuelas, y construir un sistema de educaci√≥n p√∫blica que est√© arraigado en la equidad. Los estudiantes que cuidamos y nutrimos merecen un sistema escolar donde se sientan seguros y donde sus identidades √∫nicas sean respetadas y valoradas.
Esto no ser√° un proceso perfecto, pero dar pasos adelante juntos es lo que importa. Seguiremos aprendiendo y ajustando a medida que avanzamos, sabiendo que el camino puede no ser siempre claro. Extendamos la gracia el uno al otro a trav√©s de nuestras conversaciones, donde quiera que estemos, con quien estemos. Damos la bienvenida a las aportaciones de nuestra comunidad (info-central.k12.or.us), incluso cuando es inc√≥modo, para que
podamos evaluar c√≥mo nuestra organizaci√≥n puede utilizar nuestro poder y nuestro privilegio para combatir el racismo donde y cuando aparezca.

Correcci√≥n: El documento muestra t√≠tulos incorrectos para Carol Stewart, que es presidenta del cap√≠tulo 124 de OSEA y Cinthia Mathis, quien es presidenta electa del cap√≠tulo 124 de OSEA. El documento a sido corregido en nuestro sitio web.

Creemos que la educaci√≥n es un derecho fundamental. Hemos hecho un esfuerzo concertado para organizar nuestro distrito en torno a los valores identificados por nuestros estudiantes, nuestro personal, nuestras familias y
nuestra comunidad. Nuestras partes interesadas claramente quieren escuelas que sean inclusivas, diversas, equitativas, seguras, respetuosas y enfocadas en todo el ni√±o.

Sin embargo, reconocemos que, como una organizaci√≥n predominantemente blanca, es
fundamental que nos apoyemos en conversaciones inc√≥modas y realmente nos desafiemos
a escucharnos y nos empujemos a encarnar un aliado verdadero y significativo. Debemos tratar de tomar medidas directas encaminadas a elevar a nuestros estudiantes que pertenecen a comunidades que han sido marginadas y atacadas durante demasiado tiempo. En el contexto de nuestras escuelas p√∫blicas, eso significa establecer pol√≠ticas y reglamentos equitativos; proporcionar un aprendizaje profesional centrado en la equidad de raza y pr√°cticas de ense√±anza culturalmente receptivas; reexaminar nuestros sistemas de disciplina; la
creaci√≥n de caminos para que los educadores de color entren y permanezcan en la
educaci√≥n para que nuestras escuelas reflejen mejor la diversidad de nuestras
comunidades; y capacitar a nuestros educadores para incorporar significativamente la raza y la equidad racial en el plan de estudios.

Es el deber fundamental de los educadores elevar a los oprimidos, y para el Distrito
Escolar Central, que incluye abordar cualquier forma de discriminaci√≥n o racismo que exista en nuestras escuelas, y construir un sistema de educaci√≥n p√∫blica que est√© arraigado en la equidad. Los estudiantes que cuidamos y nutrimos merecen un sistema escolar donde se sientan seguros y donde sus identidades √∫nicas sean respetadas y valoradas.
Esto no ser√° un proceso perfecto, pero dar pasos adelante juntos es lo que importa. Seguiremos aprendiendo y ajustando a medida que avanzamos, sabiendo que el camino puede no ser siempre claro. Extendamos la gracia el uno al otro a trav√©s de nuestras conversaciones, donde quiera que estemos, con quien estemos. Damos la bienvenida a las aportaciones de nuestra comunidad (info-central.k12.or.us), incluso cuando es inc√≥modo, para que
podamos evaluar c√≥mo nuestra organizaci√≥n puede utilizar nuestro poder y nuestro privilegio para combatir el racismo donde y cuando aparezca.

Correcci√≥n: El documento muestra t√≠tulos incorrectos para Carol Stewart, que es presidenta del cap√≠tulo 124 de OSEA y Cinthia Mathis, quien es presidenta electa del cap√≠tulo 124 de OSEA. El documento a sido corregido en nuestro sitio web.

post_text:
Statement from the Board of Central School District 13J, Superintendent Jennifer Kubista, the Central Education Association, and the Oregon School Employees Association Chapter 124 on the killing of George Floyd and need to address institutional racism in our public schools:
Dear families, staff, community of Central School District 13J,
In the past weeks, we have lifted our voices and hearts toward those who have been marginalized and mistreated because of their race, because they are Black or Brown. The systemic racism in our nation has been brought to the forefront of our community awareness by the recent death of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor, and many others.
We believe education is a fundamental right. We have made a concerted effort to organize our district around values identified by our students, our staff, our families, and our community. Our stakeholders clearly want schools which are inclusive, diverse, equitable, safe, respectful, and focused on the whole child.
However, we recognize that as a predominantly white organization, it‚Äôs critical that we lean into uncomfortable conversations and truly challenge ourselves to listen and push ourselves to embody true and meaningful allyship. We must seek to take direct action aimed at uplifting our students who belong to communities that have been marginalized and attacked for too long. In the context of our public schools, that means instituting equitable policies and regulations; providing professional learning focused on race equity and culturally responsive teaching practices; re-examining our discipline systems; creating pathways for educators of color to enter and remain in education so our schools better reflect the diversity of our communities; and training our educators to meaningfully incorporate race and racial equity into curriculum.
It is the fundamental duty of educators to uplift the oppressed, and for the Central School District, that includes addressing any form of discrimination or racism that exists in our schools, and building a public education system that is rooted in equity. The students we care for and nurture deserve a school system where they feel safe and where their unique identities are respected and valued.
This won‚Äôt be a perfect process, but taking steps forward together is what matters. We will continue to learn and adjust as we go, knowing that the path may not always be clear. Let us extend grace to each other through our conversations, wherever we are, whomever we‚Äôre with. We welcome input from our community (info@central.k12.or.us), even when it is uncomfortable, so we can evaluate how our organization can use our power and our privilege to combat racism wherever and whenever it appears.

Correction: The document shows incorrect titles for Carol Stewart, who is OSEA Chapter 124 president, and Cynthia Mathis, who is OSEA Chapter 124 president-elect. The document has been corrected on our website.

post_text:
Guidance for 2020-21 is here!
Dear Central School District 13J families,
The guidance for the 2020-21 school year has arrived!

We are reviewing the guidance from the Oregon Department of Education and the Oregon Health Authority now for Ready Schools, Safe Learners.

We will build teams and include community partners to create a system of teaching and learning at Central School District that will merge in-person and distance-learning approaches, while optimizing safety for students, staff, and the community as a whole.

As we move forward, here are the eight key points to keep our schools safe for learners and educators, including:
Public health protocols -- updating our communicable disease management plan to specifically address the prevention of the spread of Covid-19
Facilities and School Operations -- cleaning, disinfecting and ventilating buildings, classrooms and learning spaces
Response to outbreak -- prevention and planning
Equity -- decision making that centers in equity
Instruction -- including instructional model options (on-site, hybrid or Comprehensive Distance Learning), and recommendations on curriculum and instruction, assessment, as well as instructional activities with a higher risk for disease spread such as Labs, CTE, Performing Arts, Physical Education.
Family and Community Engagement -- partnership in planning and maintaining clear communication
Mental, Social and Emotional health -- resources and strategies
Staffing and Personnel -- public health training, supports and professional learning

Throughout the summer, the district will keep families and the community informed, so please watch for consistent voice messages and emails. We are required by the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) to have our plan reviewed by the Central School District Board of Directors and submitted to ODE no later than August 15th. We will continue to post all updates on the district website that can be located at www.central.k12.or.us.

The Oregon Department of Education has made it clear to school districts that this is a ‚Äúliving‚Äù document. Changes to the guidelines could take place over the summer months, and we will continue to modify and adjust as we receive new guidance.
Continue to give grace and patience with yourselves, with us and each other, and continue to stay safe and healthy over the summer.

https://www.oregon.gov/ode/students-and-family/healthsafety/Pages/Planning-for-the-2020-21-School-Year.aspx?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdeliver

Estimadas familias del Distrito Escolar Central13J,
¬°La nueva orientaci√≥n para el a√±o escolar 2020-2021 ha llegado!
Estamos revisando la orientaci√≥n del Departamento de Educaci√≥n de Oreg√≥n y la Autoridad de Salud de Oreg√≥n ahora para Escuelas Preparadas, Estudiantes Seguros.
Crearemos equipos e incluiremos socios comunitarios para crear un sistema de ense√±anza y aprendizaje en el Distrito Escolar Central que fusionar√° enfoques de aprendizaje en persona y a distancia, al tiempo que optimiza la seguridad para los estudiantes, el personal y la comunidad en su conjunto.
A medida que avanzamos, estos son los ocho puntos clave para mantener nuestras escuelas seguras para los estudiantes y educadores, incluyendo:
Protocolos de salud p√∫blica -- la actualizaci√≥n de nuestro plan de gesti√≥n de enfermedades transmisibles para abordar espec√≠ficamente la prevenci√≥n de la propagaci√≥n de Covid-19
Instalaciones y Operaciones Escolares -- limpieza, desinfecci√≥n y ventilaci√≥n de edificios, aulas y espacios de aprendizaje
Respuesta a la prevenci√≥n y planificaci√≥n de brotes
Equidad -- toma de decisiones que se centran en la equidad
Instrucci√≥n: incluyendo opciones de modelos de instrucci√≥n (en el sitio, h√≠brido o aprendizaje integral a distancia), y recomendaciones sobre curr√≠culo e instrucci√≥n, evaluaci√≥n, as√≠ como actividades de instrucci√≥n con un mayor riesgo de propagaci√≥n de enfermedades como laboratorios, CTE, Artes Esc√©nicas, Educaci√≥n F√≠sica.
Participaci√≥n de la familia y la comunidad -- asociaci√≥n en la planificaci√≥n y el mantenimiento de una comunicaci√≥n clara
Salud mental, social y emocional -- recursos y estrategias
Personal: capacitaci√≥n en salud p√∫blica, apoyos y aprendizaje profesional
Durante todo el verano, el distrito mantendr√° informados a las familias y a la comunidad, as√≠ que, por favor, vea seguido los correos electr√≥nicos y escuche los mensajes de voz. El Departamento de Educaci√≥n de Oreg√≥n (ODE) nos exige que nuestro plan sea revisado por la Junta Directiva del Distrito Escolar Central y que se env√≠e a ODE a m√°s tardar el 15 de agosto. Continuaremos publicando todas las actualizaciones en el sitio web del distrito que se pueden encontrar en www.central.k12.or.us.
El Departamento de Educaci√≥n de Oreg√≥n ha dejado claro a los distritos escolares que este es un documento "activo". Los cambios en las directrices podr√≠an tomar lugar durante los meses de verano, y continuaremos modific√°ndolo y ajust√°ndolo a medida que recibamos nuevas directrices.
Contin√∫e siendo amable y paciente con ustedes mismos, con nosotros y los dem√°s, y siga manteni√©ndose seguros y sanos durante el verano.

post_text:
ATTENTION PARENTS and POLK COUNTY YOUTH!!
Do you wish there were more fun things for teens to be involved with in your area? So do we! The Polk County Family & Community Outreach Department wants to help make this a reality in your community! Thanks to some generous grant funding, we have the opportunity to fund some cool youth programs in Polk County.

The first step to getting these awesome projects in your community is hearing from local teens on what they are interested in doing! If you are a middle or high school student, please complete the survey (link below). Others, please share this survey link! Once we have heard the voices of our youth, we will release Youth Activities Grants to implement the ideas.

Survey Link: https://forms.gle/rCtbRqjtiE26JUzi9

Additionally, we will pick four lucky participants to win $25 gift cards to Dutch Bros or another local vendor of their choice. Just add your email address in the form after the survey to enter into the drawing. Brent DeMoe--Director, Polk County Family & Community Outreach Department

post_text:
A letter to our communities, from Central School District 13J, City of Independence, City of Monmouth, Oregon - Government, Western Oregon University and Rep. Paul Evans
CIUDAD DE INDEPENDENCE ‚Ä¢ CIUDAD DE MONMOUTH ‚Ä¢DISTRITO ESCOLAR 13J ‚Ä¢ UNIVERSIDAD DEL OESTE DE OREGON‚Ä¢

9 de junio del 2020
Estimado miembro de la comunidad,
En las √∫ltimas semanas, nuestra naci√≥n y nuestras comunidades se han conmocionado por la muerte de George Floyd a manos de la polic√≠a de Minneapolis. Esta tragedia fue sin sentido o aborrecible. Las muertes de George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery y muchos otros que han perdido la vida son evidencia de profundas fracturas sociales de racismo que persisten. Debemos tomar medidas para asegurar que nuestras comunidades se adhieran a los valores de respeto e inclusi√≥n. Cualquier acto de racismo es un ataque a toda la comunidad.
Este tipo de acciones son una ofensa a nuestros valores como naci√≥n, estado y comunidad. Como l√≠deres comunitarios, declaramos inequ√≠vocamente que cuando alguna de las comunidades de nuestra naci√≥n experimenta actos de odio y racismo, nos vemos obligados a unirnos y reafirmar nuestro compromiso con nuestros valores y objetivos fundamentales de inclusi√≥n, comunidad, diversidad y respeto.
Tenemos la suerte de que nuestras organizaciones, el Distrito Escolar Central, la Ciudad de Independence, la Ciudad de Monmouth, la Universidad del Oeste de Oreg√≥n y el Representante Paul Evans, tengan una asociaci√≥n excepcional. En las pr√≥ximas semanas, organizaremos un foro para que los l√≠deres comunitarios, invitados por nuestros respectivos alcaldes, se unan a un di√°logo para determinar los pasos apropiados para mejorar las relaciones entre nuestros residentes. Estos esfuerzos se llevar√°n a la acabo en la Universidad (Western) y nos permitir√°n escuchar a todos. Juntos, podemos establecer prioridades que mejoren nuestro clima general. Como l√≠deres comunitarios, nuestro objetivo es asegurar que todos sean bienvenidos y se les proporcione un entorno que nos permita prosperar.
Venimos a ustedes ahora porque sabemos que muchos de nosotros estamos teniendo conversaciones en nuestros hogares, en nuestros lugares de trabajo y en nuestros campus. Queremos asegurarle que juntos estamos comprometidos a crear una comunidad m√°s segura e inclusiva.
Los actos de racismo y discriminaci√≥n no tienen cabida aqu√≠. Para ser claros, denunciamos cualquier forma de odio en nuestras comunidades, naci√≥n y mundo, y los alentamos a hacer lo mismo.
Sus vecinos,

Venimos a ustedes ahora porque sabemos que muchos de nosotros estamos teniendo conversaciones en nuestros hogares, en nuestros lugares de trabajo y en nuestros campus. Queremos asegurarle que juntos estamos comprometidos a crear una comunidad m√°s segura e inclusiva.
Los actos de racismo y discriminaci√≥n no tienen cabida aqu√≠. Para ser claros, denunciamos cualquier forma de odio en nuestras comunidades, naci√≥n y mundo, y los alentamos a hacer lo mismo.
Sus vecinos,

post_text:
A letter to our communities, from Central School District 13J, City of Independence, City of Monmouth, Oregon - Government, Rep. Paul Evans, and Western Oregon University.

Dear community member,
In past weeks, our nation and our communities have been shocked by George Floyd‚Äôs death at the hands of Minneapolis police. This tragedy was senseless and abhorrent. The deaths of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, Ahmaud Arbery, and many others who have lost their lives are evidence of deep social fractures of racism that persist. We must take action to ensure that our communities adhere to the values of respect and inclusion. Any act of racism is an attack on the whole community.
These types of actions are an affront to our values as a nation, state, and community. As community leaders, we state unequivocally that when any one of the communities in our nation experiences acts of hate and racism, we are compelled to come together and reaffirm our commitment to our core values and goals of inclusion, community, diversity and respect.
We are fortunate our organizations, Central School District, City of Independence, City of Monmouth, Western Oregon University, and Rep. Paul Evans, have an outstanding partnership. In the coming weeks, we will be organizing a forum for community leaders, invited by our respective mayors, to join in a dialog to determine appropriate steps to improve relations among our residents. These efforts will be hosted at Western and will allow all of us to be heard. Together, we can establish priorities that will improve our overall climate. As community leaders, it is our goal to ensure everyone is welcome and is provided with an environment that empowers us to thrive.
We come to you now because we know that many of us are having conversations in our homes, at our places of work, and on our campuses. We want to assure you that together we are committed to creating a safer and more inclusive community.
Acts of racism and discrimination have no place here. To be clear, we denounce any form of hate in our communities, nation and the world, and we encourage you to do the same.

post_text:
Attention Class of 2024! (That's you, 8th-graders!)
Your teachers will be at Talmadge today from 1 to 4 passing out envelopes that contain an 8th-grade Certificate of Completion, notes from their teachers, and a CHS Class of 2024 T-shirt.
We will be using the north bus loop with the covered breezeway - just like normal school day pick-up/drop off.

Also, be watching the mail this week for a welcome from Central High School!
We will be sending another communication the first week of August that will be an invitation for our ninth grade orientation. This could be virtual or in-person, depending on how things go, but we are looking forward to welcoming in our new students!

shared_text:
Mr. and Ms. Central Pageant 2019-2020
June 5 at 11:00 PM ¬∑

In the beginning of quarantine we (the coordinators) got together with all the contestants on zoom and talked about how we should proceed with the pageant this year. They are all so gracious and kind to each other they decided that it would be unfair to have a ‚Äúwinner‚Äù so we decided on individual titles. However, after all of the hard work and care they all put in we decided it wouldn‚Äôt be the same if we didn‚Äôt have a Mr. and Ms. Central. So we asked our principal and activities director to help us out in deciding who to award! They were chosen based on their hard work on their videos and the money they raised. Even though we do have a Mr. and Ms. Central this year, all contestants will be receiving a prize and title. The most important thing about all of this is that the contestants raised $10,321 with your support! See below for titles:)

Individual Titles:
Mr. and Ms. Fundraiser is Jordan Clark and Hazel Lydum
Mr. and Ms. Talent is Broden Lutz and Meagan Mendazona
Mr. and Ms. Punctuality is Harrison Eberly and Chayann Partain
Mr. and Ms. Outgoing is Chase Magill and Aby Mabry
Mr. and Ms. Congeniality is Cesar Murillo and Bailey Padilla

And Mr. and Ms. Central is (drumroll‚Ä¶)

Jordan Clark and Hazel Lydum!

Congratulations to everyone, you are all great! Thank you all for supporting us. This will be our last post.

post_text:
A message from Dr. Jennifer Kubista and the Central School District Administrative Leadership:

Dear families, staff, community of Central School District 13J,

Tomorrow, June 5, we celebrate the accomplishments of the Class of 2020. Through trials and tribulations, the likes of which we have not seen in decades, they have persevered. We are all proud of our Central graduates! The Awarding of the Diplomas will begin in the morning and last all day, giving us a chance to honor each student. For details on the ceremony, and for a link to the Senior Awards program, click here.

In this moment in time as we prepare for graduation and celebration, I would like to pause and acknowledge the hurt that many in our communities and country are experiencing with the recent events related to the death of George Floyd. These events serve to remind us of the systemic racism, injustice, and inequities that occur in our systems related to race.

On Monday, June 1st I shared a statement (link to the statement: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3634qO2ppa4&disable_polymer=true) as we began our Central Board of Directors Meetings related to my educational philosophy. My job as the superintendent is to build and support highly effective staff and principals, engage students, engage families, involve the community, build leadership teams and govern the school district in ways that support lifelong learning and growing for every student, and support their success.

This privilege, as the Superintendent, and opportunity as an educator is and always will be grounded in equity.
Children educated in an equitable and diverse community make significant impacts and differences in communities and the world today. Equitable teaching increases student learning, growth and achievement. Equitable leadership increases staff teaching and learning, so student learning, growth and achievement occurs. Electing quality individuals to govern the school district and to stay in the conversations and to advocate for equitable and ethical policy decisions is imperative so every child can learn and grow. And we do this, even when it gets hard.

We are continuing to do this here in Central School District.

We, as a community, must continue these conversations, work together, support one another, and stand together when injustice takes place. To all the students, colleagues and community members of color, I continue to stand with you, to learn and be in the conversations as we work to unroot racism within our society. We must continue to care, support and learn from one another.

How might we do this? We must build and have safe spaces in our schools and community, allowing for open, honest, and intentional conversations. It is clear from what we see happening throughout the country - even in our two towns of Independence and Monmouth - that a large portion of our society is unheard and disregarded.

We know that we can start by encouraging tough conversations and listening. Listening leads to learning. Collectively we have the power to effect positive change.
If you are need of help, remember, you are not alone. Below is a list of resources should you need someone to talk with.

As we send our amazing seniors onto their next steps, know that you are not going into the world alone. We believe in you and in your abilities. Know that it‚Äôs not only up to you to change this world -- it‚Äôs up to all of us. And tomorrow, we are excited to celebrate you. We are Central and Panther strong, and our community will always strive to be here to support our graduates and each other.

Enjoy the day and your accomplishments as we, staff, families, and community are so very proud of you!

Central Health and Wellness Center -- centralhealthandwellnesscenter.org 503-838-0045
Polk County Behavioral Health -- www.co.polk.or.us/bh (503) 623-9289, current clients call (503) 623-9289
National Suicide Prevention Lifeline -- suicidepreventionlifeline.org 1-800-273-8255
Trauma Informed Oregon -- traumainformedoregon.org
Safe Oregon -- safeoregon.com
TMS Counseling Center -- https://sites.google.com/central.k12.or.us/tmscounseling/home
CHS Counseling Office -- https://sites.google.com/view/chs-school-counseling/home

Sincerely,
Dr. Jennifer Kubista and the Central School District Administrative Leadership

Estimadas familias, personal, comunidad del Distrito Escolar Central 13J,
Ma√±ana, 5 de junio, celebramos los logros de la Clase de 2020. A trav√©s de pruebas y tribulaciones, como las que no hemos visto en d√©cadas, han perseverado. ¬°Todos estamos orgullosos de nuestros graduados de Central! La entrega de los diplomas comenzar√° por la ma√±ana y durar√° todo el d√≠a, d√°ndonos la oportunidad de honrar a cada estudiante. Para obtener m√°s informaci√≥n sobre la ceremonia y un enlace al programa de entrega de diplomas para los graduados, haga clic aqu√≠.

En este momento mientras nos preparamos para la graduaci√≥n y la celebraci√≥n, me gustar√≠a hacer una pausa y reconocer el dolor que muchos en nuestras comunidades y pa√≠ses est√°n experimentando con los recientes acontecimientos relacionados con la muerte de George Floyd. Estos eventos nos sirven para recordarnos el racismo sist√©mico, la injusticia y las desigualdades que ocurren en nuestros sistemas relacionados con la raza.

El lunes 1 de junio compart√≠ una declaraci√≥n al comenzar nuestras reuniones de la Junta Directiva del Distrito Central relacionadas con mi filosof√≠a educativa. Mi trabajo como superintendente es construir y apoyar personal y directores altamente efectivos, involucrar a los estudiantes, involucrar a las familias, involucrar a la comunidad, construir equipos de liderazgo y gobernar el distrito escolar de maneras que apoyen el aprendizaje permanente y el crecimiento para cada estudiante, y apoyen su √©xito.

Este privilegio, como Superintendente, y la oportunidad como educador es y siempre se basar√° en la equidad.
‚Ä¢ Los ni√±os educados en una comunidad equitativa y diversa tienen impactos y diferencias significativas en las comunidades y el mundo actual.
‚Ä¢ La ense√±anza equitativa aumenta el aprendizaje, el crecimiento y el logro.
‚Ä¢ El liderazgo equitativo aumenta la ense√±anza y el aprendizaje del personal, por lo que se produce el aprendizaje, el crecimiento y el logro de los estudiantes.
‚Ä¢ Elegir a personas de calidad para gobernar el distrito escolar y permanecer en las conversaciones y abogar por decisiones de pol√≠tica equitativas y √©ticas es imperativo para que cada ni√±o pueda aprender y crecer. Y hacemos esto, incluso cuando se pone dif√≠cil.
Continuamos haciendo esto aqu√≠ en el Distrito Escolar Central.

Nosotros, como comunidad, debemos continuar estas conversaciones, trabajar juntos, apoyarnos unos a otros y permanecer unidos cuando se produce la injusticia. A todos los estudiantes, colegas y miembros de la comunidad de color, sigo con ustedes, para aprender y estar en las conversaciones mientras trabajamos para desarraigar el racismo dentro de nuestra sociedad. Debemos seguir cuid√°ndose, apoyando y aprendiendo unos de otros.

¬øC√≥mo podr√≠amos hacer esto? Debemos construir y tener espacios seguros en nuestras escuelas y comunidad, permitiendo conversaciones abiertas, honestas e intencionales. De lo que vemos que sucede en todo el pa√≠s -incluso en nuestras dos ciudades de Independence y Monmouth- se desprende claramente que una gran parte de nuestra sociedad es inaudible e ignorada
Sabemos que podemos empezar por alentar conversaciones dif√≠ciles y escuchar. Escuchar conduce al aprendizaje. Colectivamente tenemos el poder de realizar un cambio positivo. Si necesita ayuda, recuerde, no est√° solo. A continuaci√≥n, se muestra una lista de recursos en caso de que necesite a alguien con quien hablar.

A medida que enviamos a nuestros incre√≠bles graduados a sus pr√≥ximos pasos, sepan que no van a entrar en el mundo solos. Creemos en ti y en tus habilidades. Sepa que no s√≥lo depende de ustedes cambiar este mundo, depende de todos nosotros. Y ma√±ana, estamos emocionados de celebrarte. Somos el Distrito Central y Panther fuertes, y nuestra comunidad siempre se esforzar√° por estar aqu√≠ para apoyar a nuestros graduados y los dem√°s.

¬°Disfrute del d√≠a y de sus logros mientras nosotros, el personal, las familias y la comunidad estamos muy orgullosos de ustedes!
Central Health and Wellness Center -- centralhealthandwellnesscenter.org 503-838-0045
Polk County Behavioral Health -- www.co.polk.or.us/bh (503) 623-9289, current clients call (503) 623-9289
National Suicide Prevention Lifeline -- suicidepreventionlifeline.org 1-800-273-8255
Trauma Informed Oregon -- traumainformedoregon.org
Safe Oregon -- safeoregon.com
TMS Counseling Center -- https://sites.google.com/central.k12.or.us/tmscounseling/home
CHS Counseling Office -- https://sites.google.com/view/chs-school-counseling/home

Dr. Jennifer Kubista y el Liderazgo Administrativo del Distrito Escolar Central

Nosotros, como comunidad, debemos continuar estas conversaciones, trabajar juntos, apoyarnos unos a otros y permanecer unidos cuando se produce la injusticia. A todos los estudiantes, colegas y miembros de la comunidad de color, sigo con ustedes, para aprender y estar en las conversaciones mientras trabajamos para desarraigar el racismo dentro de nuestra sociedad. Debemos seguir cuid√°ndose, apoyando y aprendiendo unos de otros.

¬øC√≥mo podr√≠amos hacer esto? Debemos construir y tener espacios seguros en nuestras escuelas y comunidad, permitiendo conversaciones abiertas, honestas e intencionales. De lo que vemos que sucede en todo el pa√≠s -incluso en nuestras dos ciudades de Independence y Monmouth- se desprende claramente que una gran parte de nuestra sociedad es inaudible e ignorada
Sabemos que podemos empezar por alentar conversaciones dif√≠ciles y escuchar. Escuchar conduce al aprendizaje. Colectivamente tenemos el poder de realizar un cambio positivo. Si necesita ayuda, recuerde, no est√° solo. A continuaci√≥n, se muestra una lista de recursos en caso de que necesite a alguien con quien hablar.

A medida que enviamos a nuestros incre√≠bles graduados a sus pr√≥ximos pasos, sepan que no van a entrar en el mundo solos. Creemos en ti y en tus habilidades. Sepa que no s√≥lo depende de ustedes cambiar este mundo, depende de todos nosotros. Y ma√±ana, estamos emocionados de celebrarte. Somos el Distrito Central y Panther fuertes, y nuestra comunidad siempre se esforzar√° por estar aqu√≠ para apoyar a nuestros graduados y los dem√°s.

¬°Disfrute del d√≠a y de sus logros mientras nosotros, el personal, las familias y la comunidad estamos muy orgullosos de ustedes!
Central Health and Wellness Center -- centralhealthandwellnesscenter.org 503-838-0045
Polk County Behavioral Health -- www.co.polk.or.us/bh (503) 623-9289, current clients call (503) 623-9289
National Suicide Prevention Lifeline -- suicidepreventionlifeline.org 1-800-273-8255
Trauma Informed Oregon -- traumainformedoregon.org
Safe Oregon -- safeoregon.com
TMS Counseling Center -- https://sites.google.com/central.k12.or.us/tmscounseling/home
CHS Counseling Office -- https://sites.google.com/view/chs-school-counseling/home

Dr. Jennifer Kubista y el Liderazgo Administrativo del Distrito Escolar Central

Superintendent Kubista shares educational philosophy

On Tuesday, June 9th, starting at 1:30 pm, we will be on a parade route to celebrate our students and everything they have accomplished this year! We will begin at IES, and will follow the route that you can find in the pictures!

Independence Elementary School
June 4 at 9:27 AM ¬∑

Hello IES Families!

On Tuesday, June 9th, starting at 1:30 pm, we will be on a parade route to celebrate our students and everything they have accomplished this year! We will begin at IES, and will follow the route that you can find in the pictures

Please find a spot along our route to join us, and you can show your IES spirit by wearing red and black or our IES gear!

We also want to remind you to practice good social distancing as you choose your place along the route. We hope to see as many of you as possible!

Tambien, deseamos recordarles de tener un distanciamiento social cuando escoja su lugar de espera en la ruta. Esperamos ver a cuantas familias posible!

The Monmouth Public Library has partnered with the Central School District to bring books to children at the meal pickup locations in Monmouth and Independence on Tuesday, June 2, and to bused meal sites on Wednesday, June 3. United Way of the Mid-Willamette Valley and the Friends of the Monmouth Library generously donated funds to purchase the new books. Youth Services Librarian Carrie Kasperick estimates at least 500 children and teens will each receive three books during the book giveaway. Books are intended for participants in the meal pickup and while supplies last!

post_text:
Central School District 13J families!

We are in the final stretch! The last day of school for K-11 is June 9.
Remember will be awarding diplomas to graduating seniors on June 5. Please watch for more information from your CHS staff for details.

If you missed Wednesday‚Äôs Kinder registration, please call your school for a packet. Don‚Äôt know your school? The transportation staff have you covered with this nifty app. Enter your address and it will tell you your school. The app can be found at central.k12.or.us, under the ‚ÄúParent‚Äù link at the top. Then choose the ‚ÄúEnrollment‚Äù link.

Information for our fifth-graders transitioning to the middle school should receive a letter from Talmadge, if you haven‚Äôt already.

If you haven‚Äôt done it yet, please take a moment and give us your thoughts on how distance learning has been for your family so far. We know you are working hard, and are a key piece to the distance learning program. Your feedback will help us learn and adjust as we prepare for the coming school year. We‚Äôve already considered some feedback: The survey is now available for you to take for each of your children, and you no longer need to be logged into a Google account. The link to the survey can be found on our district website, central.k12.or.us.

The Monmouth Public Library has partnered with the Central School District to bring books to children at the meal pickup locations in Monmouth and Independence on Tuesday, June 2, and to bused meal sites on Wednesday, June 3. United Way of the Mid-Willamette Valley and the Friends of the Monmouth Library generously donated funds to purchase the new books. Youth Services Librarian Carrie Kasperick estimates at least 500 children and teens will each receive three books during the book giveaway. Books are intended for participants in the meal pickup and while supplies last!

Thank you all for your continued grace and patience through this unprecedented time! We will continue to inform you of opportunities available, as well as general news from the district. We know the next big question is: What will school look like in fall? Know that we are working hard on preparing for whatever that will bring, and waiting on guidance from the Oregon Department of Education and the Oregon Health Authority, as well as from the governor‚Äôs office.

As always, if you have any questions, please email us at info@central.k12.or.us, and follow us on Facebook.

Estimadas familias del Distrito Escolar Central,

¬°Estamos en la recta final! El √∫ltimo d√≠a de escuela para los grados K-11 es el 9 de junio. ‚ÄúRemember‚Äù otorgar√° diplomas a los estudiantes graduados el 5 de junio. Este al pendiente para obtener m√°s informaci√≥n de su personal de CHS.

Si se perdi√≥ el registro de k√≠nder el mi√©rcoles, por favor llame a su escuela para un recibir un paquete por correo. ¬øNo conoces tu escuela? El personal de transporte lo tiene cubierto con esta ingeniosa aplicaci√≥n.

La informaci√≥n para nuestros estudiantes de quinto grado que pasan a la escuela secundaria debe recibir una carta de Talmadge, si es que a√∫n no lo ha hecho.

Si a√∫n no lo ha hecho, por favor t√≥mese un momento y denos su opini√≥n sobre c√≥mo ha sido el aprendizaje a distancia para su familia hasta ahora. Sabemos que est√° trabajando arduamente, y es una pieza clave para el programa de aprendizaje a distancia. Sus comentarios nos ayudar√°n a aprender y ajustarnos a medida que nos preparamos para el pr√≥ximo a√±o escolar. Ya hemos considerado algunos comentarios: La encuesta ya est√° disponible para completar por cada uno de tus hijos y ya no necesitas iniciar sesi√≥n en una cuenta de Google.

La Biblioteca P√∫blica de Monmouth se ha asociado con el Distrito Escolar Central para llevar libros a los ni√±os en los lugares de recolecci√≥n de comidas en Monmouth e Independence el martes 2 de junio, y a sitios de comidas en autob√∫s el mi√©rcoles 3 de junio. United Way of the Mid-Willamette Valley y los amigos de la Biblioteca P√∫blica de Monmouth generosamente donaron fondos para comprar los nuevos libros. La bibliotecaria de servicios juveniles Carrie Kasperick estima que al menos 500 ni√±os y adolescentes recibir√°n tres libros cada uno durante el sorteo. ¬°Los libros est√°n destinados a los participantes cuando recojan las comidas y mientras duren los suministros!

¬°Gracias a todos por su continua amabilidad y paciencia a trav√©s de este tiempo sin precedentes! Continuaremos informando de las oportunidades disponibles, as√≠ como las noticias generales del distrito. Sabemos que la siguiente gran pregunta es: ¬øC√≥mo ser√° la escuela en oto√±o? Sepa que estamos trabajando arduamente en prepararnos para lo que eso traer√°, y esperando la gu√≠a del Departamento de Educaci√≥n de Oreg√≥n y la Autoridad de Salud de Oreg√≥n, as√≠ como de la oficina de la gobernadora.

Como siempre, si tiene alguna pregunta, env√≠enos un correo electr√≥nico a info-central.k12.or.us y s√≠ganos en Facebook.

Youth Services Librarian Carrie Kasperick estimates at least 500 children and teens will each receive three books during the book giveaway. Thank you all for your continued grace and patience through this unprecedented time! We will continue to inform you of opportunities available, as well as general news from the district. We know the next big question is: What will school look like in fall? Know that we are working hard on preparing for whatever that will bring, and waiting on guidance from the Oregon Department of Education and the Oregon Health Authority, as well as from the governor‚Äôs office.

As always, if you have any questions, please email us at info@central.k12.or.us, and follow us on Facebook.

Estimadas familias del Distrito Escolar Central,

¬°Estamos en la recta final! El √∫ltimo d√≠a de escuela para los grados K-11 es el 9 de junio. ‚ÄúRemember‚Äù otorgar√° diplomas a los estudiantes graduados el 5 de junio. Este al pendiente para obtener m√°s informaci√≥n de su personal de CHS.

Si se perdi√≥ el registro de k√≠nder el mi√©rcoles, por favor llame a su escuela para un recibir un paquete por correo. ¬øNo conoces tu escuela? El personal de transporte lo tiene cubierto con esta ingeniosa aplicaci√≥n.

La informaci√≥n para nuestros estudiantes de quinto grado que pasan a la escuela secundaria debe recibir una carta de Talmadge, si es que a√∫n no lo ha hecho.

Si a√∫n no lo ha hecho, por favor t√≥mese un momento y denos su opini√≥n sobre c√≥mo ha sido el aprendizaje a distancia para su familia hasta ahora. Sabemos que est√° trabajando arduamente, y es una pieza clave para el programa de aprendizaje a distancia. Sus comentarios nos ayudar√°n a aprender y ajustarnos a medida que nos preparamos para el pr√≥ximo a√±o escolar. Ya hemos considerado algunos comentarios: La encuesta ya est√° disponible para completar por cada uno de tus hijos y ya no necesitas iniciar sesi√≥n en una cuenta de Google.

La Biblioteca P√∫blica de Monmouth se ha asociado con el Distrito Escolar Central para llevar libros a los ni√±os en los lugares de recolecci√≥n de comidas en Monmouth e Independence el martes 2 de junio, y a sitios de comidas en autob√∫s el mi√©rcoles 3 de junio. United Way of the Mid-Willamette Valley y los amigos de la Biblioteca P√∫blica de Monmouth generosamente donaron fondos para comprar los nuevos libros. La bibliotecaria de servicios juveniles Carrie Kasperick estima que al menos 500 ni√±os y adolescentes recibir√°n tres libros cada uno durante el sorteo. ¬°Los libros est√°n destinados a los participantes cuando recojan las comidas y mientras duren los suministros!

¬°Gracias a todos por su continua amabilidad y paciencia a trav√©s de este tiempo sin precedentes! Continuaremos informando de las oportunidades disponibles, as√≠ como las noticias generales del distrito. Sabemos que la siguiente gran pregunta es: ¬øC√≥mo ser√° la escuela en oto√±o? Sepa que estamos trabajando arduamente en prepararnos para lo que eso traer√°, y esperando la gu√≠a del Departamento de Educaci√≥n de Oreg√≥n y la Autoridad de Salud de Oreg√≥n, as√≠ como de la oficina de la gobernadora.

Como siempre, si tiene alguna pregunta, env√≠enos un correo electr√≥nico a info-central.k12.or.us y s√≠ganos en Facebook.

post_text:
One of our amazing staff shared this story about her students, and asked us to pass it on! #CentralStrong #Distancelearning doesn't stop us!

In the midst of all that is going on, I just wanted to share with you a success story. Before the "virus vacation," I was working with two sixth grade girls on a fundraiser. When they learned that Mr. Glasmann's teenage nephew had cancer, they wanted to help. They did traditional things around the school to raise money (collected change, sold trinkets, and even hosted a Rock, Paper, Scissors tournament). But beyond that, they made phone calls to people they knew and asked them to donate. This weekend, I was privileged to deliver a check for $671 to Mr. Glasmann to help his sister and nephew. These girls saw a need, felt compassion, and then went to work in a way that is rare for kids their age.

We've got some great kids in this district!

post_text:
Central School District 13J families,
The end of the 2019-20 school year is in sight, with the last day of school coming in just a few weeks! While we are working on a summer learning program, we want all of our students and families, and staff to finish strong!

May 27 is a big day! Mark your calendars for your seniors and your incoming kinders. Seniors will be able to pick up caps, gowns, and other things to wrap up their K-12 careers and prepare for the big day on June 5!

Kindergarten registration will also be on May 27, moved to the Talmadge Middle School south parking lot from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m.! Please arrive alphabetically according to your last name and be prepared to tell us your address so we can get you registered at the right school!
Last name A-G: 5:30-6:10
Last name H-O: 6:10-6:50
Last name P-Z: 6:50-7:30

As you get your children ready for the new school year -- even amidst the uncertainty -- we want to remind you about immunizations.
The Central Health and Wellness Center is open for immunizations! The center is open Tuesday and Thursday, 8 a.m. to noon, and Wednesday, 1 to 5 p.m. for medical visits. They also are open on tuesday and Thursday, 1 to 5 p.m. and Wednesday 8 a.m. to noon for immunizations!
Immunizations required for school-aged children are:
Kindergarten: MMR, Polio, Varicella, DTaP, Hepatitis A and Hepatitis B required; annual influenza vaccine recommended.
Grade 7: All of the above plus TDaP required; Meningitis, HPV and annual influenza recommended.

Please stay safe and healthy, maintaining physical distance. We are so proud of all of you, and of all our educators -- and that includes our parents working hard to help us teach students. Our second parent survey is now live, and we welcome your feedback.

As always, if you have questions or concerns, please write us at info@central.k12.or.us.

#MrandMsCentral #pageant contestants wanted to perform their dance routine virtually! Congratulations to everyone for raising more than $10,000 for #CASA!

We have raised a total of $10,242.61 because of your support! To everyone who donated, shared our posts, and followed us thank you! We could‚Äôve not done this without you. All of the money donated will be given to Polk County C.A.S.A. in support of foster children in our community. If you would like to support us more you can go to http://tinyurl.com/central-High-Pageant through Monday night. Thank you again and be on the lookout for title announcements!
shared_text:
Mr. and Ms. Central Pageant 2019-2020 posted a video to playlist Group Contestant Videos.
May 23 at 1:00 PM ¬∑

Every year at our pageant contestants perform two dances. They had just learned the choreography for one of the dances when quarantine began. The group decided they still wanted to perform the dance, but this decision proved harder than we expected. And after only two rehearsals together, (which happened 3 months ago!) each contestant had to relearn and record the dance on their own! However, they persevered and although we may not be winning any dance competitions anytime soon, we have raised a total of $10,242.61 because of your support! To everyone who donated, shared our posts, and followed us thank you! We could‚Äôve not done this without you. All of the money donated will be given to Polk County C.A.S.A. in support of foster children in our community. If you would like to support us more you can go to http://tinyurl.com/central-High-Pageant through Monday night. Thank you again and be on the lookout for title announcements!

The group decided they still wanted to perform the dance, but this decision proved harder than we expected. And after only two rehearsals together, (which happened 3 months ago!) each contestant had to relearn and record the dance on their own! However, they persevered and although we may not be winning any dance competitions anytime soon, we have raised a total of $10,242.61 because of your support! To everyone who donated, shared our posts, and followed us thank you! We could‚Äôve not done this without you. All of the money donated will be given to Polk County C.A.S.A. in support of foster children in our community. If you would like to support us more you can go to http://tinyurl.com/central-High-Pageant through Monday night. Thank you again and be on the lookout for title announcements!

Breaking news about kindergarten registration!

The first kindergarten registration opportunity will be on May 27th at Central High School from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m. Please arrive alphabetically according to your last name and be prepared to tell us your address so we can get you registered at the right school!

Contestant Highlight Day 10 is Cesar Andres Murillo! His parents are Edila Fernandez Murillo & Antonio Medardo Garcia Diaz and he was born on January 3rd, 2002. His favorite quote is ‚Äústrength and growth come only through continuous struggle and effort."

#MrandMsCentral #pageant #CASA #Panthers
shared_text:
Mr. and Ms. Central Pageant 2019-2020
May 15 at 10:00 AM ¬∑

Contestant Highlight Day 10 is Cesar Andres Murillo! His parents are Edila Fernandez Murillo & Antonio Medardo Garcia Diaz and he was born on January 3rd, 2002. His favorite quote is ‚Äústrength and growth come only through continuous struggle and effort". If he could have any superpower it would be "the ability to teleport, so I could visit any location on Earth in seconds, all while not having to worry about gas". The people who have had the greatest influence on him is "definitely my parents. They always put my siblings and I ahead of themselves. They have showed me what determination, hard work, and kindness look like". When asked what his favorite year of high school is he said "It‚Äôs difficult to pick just one year because every high school year has its ups and downs, but my Senior year has been such a delightful experience because I finished a lot of the goals I had for myself in the beginning. I was able to become more involved, meet so many amazing individuals, and just had such a fun time making memories". Watch for more content of Cesar today!

The greatest influence in his life has been "my mom, she has done many amazing things and is always there when I need her". His favorite year of high school was "sophomore year; choir won at state, one of our shows sold out, and I had a ton of fun!". Keep watching for more stuff from Brody today!

post_text:
We are Springing into Fun with our At-Home After School program, which has officially kicked off!

Parents and students can go to the At-Home After School program Google Site, where they can enter a Google Classroom for either K-5 or 6-8. Each day has a fun theme: Makers Monday (STEM), Tech Tuesday (STRIDE), Wacky Wednesday (Enrichment), Thumbs Up Thursday (Check in for fitness, nutrition, well being), and FUN Friday (Game Day).

The program runs 3-5:30 p.m. Monday through Friday, with 3-4 p.m. acting as office hours. Live sessions will be from 4-5 in Google Classrooms or Google Meet. 5-5:30 is a time to wrap up, answer questions or make connections.

Learn more:
shared_text:
SITES.GOOGLE.COM
CSD ELO Program

post_text:
Contestant Highlight Day 7 is Meagan Mendazona! She's the daughter of Joe & Claudine Mendazona and was born on November 24, 2001. Her favorite quote is "You don't have to be great to start, but you have to start to be great" -Zig Zig.

#MrandMsCentral #Pageant #CASA
shared_text:
Mr. and Ms. Central Pageant 2019-2020
May 12 at 5:00 PM ¬∑

Contestant Highlight Day 7 is Meagan Mendazona! She's the daughter of Joe & Claudine Mendazona and was born on November 24, 2001. Her favorite quote is "You don't have to be great to start, but you have to start to be great" -Zig Zig. If she could have any superpower it would be "teleportation, because there are so many places that I want to see and live in and if I was able to teleport then I could go to a new place every day. I also really don't like airports so it would be nice to be able to avoid them". The greatest influence in her life has been "my parents have been my greatest influences throughout my life. They have always pushed me to be my best self whether it's in the classroom, on the basketball court, or just in everyday life. They have supported me through it all and without them I'm not sure where I would be today". Her favorite year of high school has been senior year, "being near the end really gave me a new appreciation of all of the moments I have left here. My friends and I have become closer than ever before and have made the most out of every day. This has been a year full of fun and laughter and has by far topped the rest of high school". Keep watching for more content from Meagan!

#MrandMsCentral #pageant continues this week!

Contestant Highlight Day 6 is Jordan Clark! He is the son of Jason and Juanita Clark and was born February 21, 2002. His favorite quote is "we can't help everyone, but everyone can help someone" - Ronald Reagan.

#CASA #fundraiser #Central
shared_text:
Mr. and Ms. Central Pageant 2019-2020
May 11 at 10:00 AM ¬∑

Contestant Highlight Day 6 is Jordan Clark! He is the son of Jason and Juanita Clark and was born February 21, 2002. His favorite quote is "we can't help everyone, but everyone can help someone" - Ronald Reagan. If he could have any superpower it would be "the power of flight. It would be a great and efficient way to bypass terrible traffic, and I could get from place to place very quickly". The person whose had the greatest influence in his life is "Probably my mom, I keep finding myself becoming more and more like the positive, good natured person she is". His favorite year of high school has been senior year, "I haven't finished it yet, but I'm enjoying it more than I remember enjoying the other years. I think it's largely due to all the newfound freedoms and responsibilities I'm finding". Keep on the lookout for more content from Jordan today!
